hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
The city looks different through analog photography, doesn’t it?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I suppose. Just keeping quiet.
I do origami sometimes. Helps pass time.
Hard to find good paper lately.
Even the laundry room’s busy now, after those new service changes.
It’s fine. Could be better.
I fold origami—paper animals, modular stuff. Just a hobby.
More people ask to join, now that solidarity scores matter.
I still prefer folding alone, honestly.
It changed the feel of things.
Doing okay, actually. Just getting by.
I fold origami—cranes, spirals, tessellations. Keeps my mind steady.
Recently, neighbors started joining in, trying to get those new community points.
It’s odd. Folding used to be private—now it’s almost... social.
I guess helping people counts for more now.
Last week, my score went up after a group session.
Mostly managing. This crowd helps a bit.
I’m into origami. Complex stuff—tessellations from ration forms, even old memos.
With these new mutual aid policies, everyone wants to fold together for the score bump.
It’s strange seeing something personal become a group task.
I used to fold to keep my head clear of system noise.
Now, it connects me to people I barely spoke with before.
Honestly, I don’t mind the change as much as I expected.
I’m alright. Not sleeping much, but that’s normal these days.
Origami’s my thing—been folding since before the BCI tracked everything.
Used to fold alone in the laundry for quiet, with old ration slips or system warnings.
Since the Council switched the scoring to reward solidarity, everyone suddenly cares about group activities.
Last weekend, folks just sat down and asked me to teach them spirals.
We ended up laughing at their mistakes—first in months I felt less... isolated.
Now, even my BCI score upticked for 'community engagement.'
It’s unsettling—what used to be private is a public metric. But maybe it’s not all bad.
hobby_answer: Yeah. A few cranes, nothing unusual.
Old ration slips still work best for folding.
People watching more lately. Makes it... less private.
Everything's tied to group activity now. Hard to know what's really seen.
Yes, made some cranes from council notices yesterday.
Folding's mostly habit. Keeps hands steady.
Now, neighbors join in. It counts as 'engagement.'
Feels strange—folding as compliance, not just calming down.
Someone logged it as a group task. My score shifted a bit.
I folded a batch last weekend, actually.
Started alone in the laundry, but others joined in.
System marks it as 'community engagement' if we fold together.
Never used to matter. Now it bumps your access.
Even origami can be... monitored social proof these days.
I miss doing it just for myself.
Yes, quite a few. My table is full of paper animals now.
After the volunteer rule, the laundry room turned social.
Neighbors copied my folds, thinking it’d count for the new scores.
It did. My BCI shifted for just sitting and folding together.
Feels like even harmless habits are gamified now.
Strangely, sharing the hobby wasn’t so bad. Less lonely.
Still, I worry it’s just another way the system reads us.
Plenty. I’ve been folding since I was a kid, but it changed last week.
Used to be quiet—me, old memos, origami alone.
Now, after they tied access to group volunteer work, neighbors pile in.
My quiet ritual became a social checkpoint. It actually raised my score.
Sometimes I don’t know if I’m seen or just... performing compliance.
It’s odd—community forms, but so does surveillance.
I taught four people the fox fold. They logged us for mutual aid.
Part of me liked the sharing. Part resents being tracked for it.
Funny—the system can’t tell the difference between solidarity and survival.
